docs.lead_paragraph: Cases of Lyme disease might be reduced by switching the focus from people and vaccinating the animals that carry it, a new study suggests. Writing in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers described an experiment in which they caught white-footed mice in a wooded area of roughly 3,000 acres in Connecticut, vaccinated them against Lyme disease, tagged them and set them free. The lead author was Dr. Jean Tsao of Michigan State University.

headline.main: Taking Lyme Fight to the Field

docs.snippet: Cases of Lyme disease might be reduced by switching the focus from people and vaccinating the animals that carry it, a new study suggests.    Writing in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers described an experiment in which...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the war against acne, the big-gun antibiotics are often unnecessary. That is the conclusion of a new study in The Lancet, which found that for acne on the face of mild to moderate severity, simple over-the-counter creams were as good as prescription antibiotics.

headline.main: Smaller Weapons in War on Acne

docs.snippet: In the war against acne, the big-gun antibiotics are often unnecessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Robert Phillips, a truck driver in Virginia, was dying of kidney failure in 1963, his younger sister, Ruth, read in a newspaper about a mother-to-son kidney transplant in Denver. Ms. Phillips picked up the phone and called the transplant doctors. Could she give one of her kidneys to her brother? she asked them.

headline.main: The Ultimate Gift: 50 Years of Organ Transplants

docs.snippet: Over the last five decades, surgeons have learned how to transplant virtually every vital organ in the human body.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first time I saw her, she seemed like any other patient that comes into the women's health clinic where I work as a nurse practitioner. She was a woman eager to take care of herself but still a bit nervous about having her annual exam. When I asked her my routine questions -- any symptoms, any past medical illnesses, any operations, any medicines or allergies, any significant family history, do you smoke or drink alcohol, any drug use -- she answered them easily.

headline.main: Her Heart's in the Right Place. Or Is It?

docs.snippet: Dextrocardia, a rare condition, means the heart's apex is positioned on the right, not the left.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving Day was fraught with fear and anxiety for my family and me. The morning before, my fourth grandson, ''Baby T,'' aka Tennyson, entered the world at a robust 8 pounds 14 ounces. His Apgar score five minutes after birth was 9 of a possible 10, indicating good color, good muscle tone, good health. But two hours later, his life hung in a precarious balance. An observant nurse noted that his color was ''not right'' -- pink above the chest but grayish below. Minutes later, the neonatologist told my daughter-in-law that her baby, who initially seemed perfectly healthy, was now ''very, very, very sick and could go either way.''

headline.main: Four Scary Days With a Newborn Grandson

docs.snippet: Persistent pulmonary hypertension in newborns is considered rare, but it is surprisingly common, afflicting an estimated 1 baby in 700.

docs.lead_paragraph: Without his hearing aids, Dr. Don Thaler has trouble holding a conversation in a crowded restaurant. With the devices in, however, the ambient noise -- the clinking of dishes, the shuffling of feet, the drone of table talk throughout the room -- can be intolerable. ''I just hate them,'' Dr. Thaler, a retired dentist in Amagansett, N.Y., said of his hearing aids -- digital ones that fit completely inside the ear canal and cost more than $7,000 for the pair. He wears them only when going out with company. Even then, he said, ''I always carry a leather pouch because inevitably I end up pulling them out of my ears.''

headline.main: Shop Smart, to Hear What You Want to Hear

docs.snippet: Hearing aids are the best way for many people to maintain a connection to the world, but they can also disappoint new users.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many immigrants come to the United States for the good life. But a new study suggests that living well can carry a cost. Over the years, researchers report, immigrants tend to become just as obese as born-and-bred Americans -- even if they are from countries where obesity is less common.
docs.snippet: Many immigrants come to the United States for the good life. But a new study suggests that living well can carry a cost.

docs.lead_paragraph: One year after British drug regulators advised against prescribing a new generation of antidepressants, except Prozac, for depressed adolescents, British doctors say they are in a frustrating bind. Warned away from using the antidepressants, they are recommending psychotherapy for their young patients instead. But under the British health system, depressed teenagers face a six- to nine-month waiting list for psychotherapy, a situation unlikely to improve in the short term.

headline.main: Help Eludes Depressed Children In Britain

docs.snippet: Warned away from using the antidepressants, British doctors are recommending psychotherapy for their young patients instead. But teenagers face a six- to nine-month waiting list.

docs.lead_paragraph: Think of it as a barrier to the barrier. Despite the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies, a new study reports that many young people may be hesitant to buy condoms because they are simply too embarrassed.
docs.snippet: Despite the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies, many young people may be hesitant to buy condoms because they are simply too embarrassed.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Freezing or reusing plastic bottles can be hazardous to your health. THE FACTS -- A widely circulated e-mail message has warned that freezing water in plastic containers can release dioxins, the same deadly group of chemicals recently used to poison Viktor A. Yushchenko, the Ukrainian presidential candidate. Dioxins are ubiquitous in the environment, so much so that most living creatures accumulate low levels. They are byproducts of combustion reactions, released into the air largely through industrial processes. Over time, they seep into the food chain. Most exposure occurs through the diet, though trace amounts can be ingested by breathing polluted air.
docs.snippet: Plastic bottles and containers, if used properly, will not expose you to chemicals.
